awd_titl_txt: Integrating Science Content and Engineering Thinking in the Elementary Classroom
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, the Integrating Science Content and Engineering Thinking in the Elementary Classroom Project will recruit Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics majors and professionals and prepare them to become elementary teachers. The project will fund 10 stipends per year over five years, resulting in the preparation of 50 elementary science teachers. In this project, the University of Massachusetts at Boston will collaborate with two Boston public elementary schools and the Conservatory Lab School to build on the idea of engineering design process as a teaching-learning approach that can be used to promote science learning. Teaching through engineering design has the potential to facilitate integrated instruction that meets the requirements of the new science education standards. Design-based learning can help students develop scientific inquiry and real world problem-solving skills, enhance discipline-specific content knowledge and critical thinking skills, and promote interest in science or engineering careers. 

This project will advance knowledge and understanding in the area of STEM teacher preparation at the elementary level by preparing elementary teachers to use engineering practices, integrated with science content, to teach science to elementary-aged children. Project outcomes will help determine the effectiveness of recent reforms in K-12 education, particularly those that call for the integration of engineering with science education, and will integrate the practices of science and engineering with didactic content.  There are very few elementary teacher preparation programs that focus exclusively on preparing elementary teachers to teach STEM content. Built into the proposed teacher preparation program are two new assessments for tracking the ability of teachers to integrate engineering and science content in the elementary classroom, the Video Case Diagnosis and the Curriculum Critique and Revision tools. With its focus on STEM at the elementary level, this unique program will utilize these two tools to determine the effectiveness of STEM integration for building science content knowledge for elementary students.

por.por_cntn:
The program supported by this NSF Noyce Track 2 grant – Integrating Science Content and Engineering Thinking in the Elementary Classroom -- focused on the idea of content integration i.e. the integration of STEM content and engineering thinking, in order to use engineering design as a motivator to teach mathematics and science content to children. Inthis case, the learning goals are not about the engineering per se, but rather engineering design as a pedagogy to help students learn the content (Moore et al., 2014). We built on the idea of engineering design process as a teaching-learning approach that can be used to promote science learning (Marx, & Mamlok-Naaman, 2005). 

We believed that teaching through engineering design had the potential to facilitate integrated instruction that met the requirements of the new science education standards. Engineering design encourages students to construct solutions to real problems using inquiry and cooperative learning processes that allow students to develop new understandings and to relate those understandings to other concepts. Design-based learning can help students develop scientific inquiry and real-world problem-solving skills (Kolodner Schunn, & Strand- Cary, 2009. During the design process, teaching and learning for understanding is emphasized (Fortus et al., 2005) and relevant science content is presented when needed and not treated simply as an “add-on” (Silk et al., 2009). We believed that engineering had a distinctadvantage at the elementary level of being something students would enjoy because of its hands-on and creative nature. Bringing engineering to the classroom is grounded in a constructionist philosophy that puts forth that people learn better when they are working with materials that allow them to design and build artifacts that are meaningful to them. In this project, we wanted to use engineering to motivate elementary students to learn math, science, reading, writing, communication, and design skills by giving them ownership of a project or process.

 We were awarded a five year NSF Noyce grant to do this work in 2017. What made thisgrant different was the design of a year-long STEM seminar that integrated Science, Math and Technology through Engineering Design thus giving science and math learning an authentic context. We based this on the community-based engineering frameworkdeveloped by Dalvi & Wendell 2014, 2015. This framework involves the finding and solving of technological problems in students’ local environments, such as their neighborhoods, community centers, or schools. A focus on the immediate urban community provides a common lens for urban students through which they can view new content. Also, solving a problem for the local community helps students identify themselves as responsible community members capable of learning and doing STEM. Withthis, the students realize that the lesson can empower them to shape their life and community, which makes them more likely to be engaged in constructing new knowledge (Buxton et al., 2008) and in learning new content and skills (Bouillion and Gomez, 2001). Finally, we also worked with literacy experts because reform movements in STEM education connect language and literacy with the development of scientific thinking. For example, the related practices of the Common Core State Standards (National Governors Association, 2010) and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS Lead States, 2013) address the language and literacy demands of science as integral to the processes and content students need for productive “beginnings” as STEM learners. As the elementary curriculum spans all academic disciplines (e.g. Science, Math, English Language Arts, Social Studies, and the Arts), elementary classrooms provide ideal sites for teaching disciplinary literacies necessary for integrated STEM learning. 

 

This approach to preparing Elementary STEM teachers was run through the Teach Next Year (TNY) Teaching Residency Program at UMass/Boston.  The TNY program places Elementary teacher candidates, or teaching residents, in an urban classroom for the entire school year. The Elementary teaching residents work under the guidance of a mentor teacher for the first half of the year designing and teaching their own units in each of the core areas of elementary education -- ELA, history and STEM (math and science).  In the second half of the year, they become the primary teacher of the classroom.  The mentor teacher, as well as a university supervisor, continue to support the teaching resident throughout the second half of the year, but the teaching resident does the bulk of the planning, designing and teaching.  

 

The Elementary Noyce candidates also completed a course focused on STEM writing. The course provides the preservice teachers with a genre-focused pedagogy as they teach their students how texts work for effective development of disciplinary ideas.

 

To date this program has prepared 49 teachers, including 34 elementary teachers, to focus on STEM content in their teaching. Of these, 35%, are teachers of color and seven are male. Finally, 63% have been hired to teach in Boston Public Schools, with the rest teaching in other urban schools in Massachusetts.
